claim: If you watch a pot of water on the stove, it will boil.

supporting.text: Water boils when it reaches its boiling point temperature, which is 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure.

attacks.text: Water boils when it reaches its boiling point temperature, which is 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure.

Such adjustments are rare and typically negligible in controlled cooking conditions, making the original argument still largely valid.
At higher altitudes, water boils below 100°C due to lower atmospheric pressure, so the claim is context-dependent.
